trans-unit.source: About Keys and Secrets
trans-unit.target: About Keys and Secrets

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault

trans-unit.source: About Keys and Secrets
trans-unit.target: About Keys and Secrets

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault enables users to store and use cryptographic keys within the Microsoft Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault enables users to store and use cryptographic keys within the Microsoft Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault supports multiple key types and algorithms and enables the use of Hardware Security Modules (HSM) for high value customer keys.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault supports multiple key types and algorithms and enables the use of Hardware Security Modules (HSM) for high value customer keys.

trans-unit.source: In addition, Azure Key Vault allows users to securely store secrets, limited size octet objects, in a Key Vault Azure Key Vault applies no specific semantics to secrets..
trans-unit.target: In addition, Azure Key Vault allows users to securely store secrets, limited size octet objects, in a Key Vault Azure Key Vault applies no specific semantics to secrets..

trans-unit.source: A Key Vault may contain a mix of keys and secrets, and access for the two types of objects is independently controlled.
trans-unit.target: A Key Vault may contain a mix of keys and secrets, and access for the two types of objects is independently controlled.

trans-unit.source: This topic
trans-unit.target: This topic

trans-unit.source: Supporting standards
trans-unit.target: Supporting standards

trans-unit.source: The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Object Signing and Encryption (JOSE) specifications at IETF are important background information for this specification:
trans-unit.target: The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Object Signing and Encryption (JOSE) specifications at IETF are important background information for this specification:

trans-unit.source: JSON Web Key (JWK)
trans-unit.target: JSON Web Key (JWK)

trans-unit.source: JSON Web Encryption (JWE)
trans-unit.target: JSON Web Encryption (JWE)

trans-unit.source: JSON Web Algorithms (JWA)
trans-unit.target: JSON Web Algorithms (JWA)

trans-unit.source: JSON Web Signature (JWS)
trans-unit.target: JSON Web Signature (JWS)

trans-unit.source: Data types
trans-unit.target: Data types

trans-unit.source: Refer to the JOSE specifications for relevant data types for Keys, Encryption and Signing.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the JOSE specifications for relevant data types for Keys, Encryption and Signing.

trans-unit.source: algorithm: A supported algorithm for a key operation,for example, RSA1_5
trans-unit.target: algorithm: A supported algorithm for a key operation,for example, RSA1_5

trans-unit.source: ciphertext-value: cipher text octets, encoded using Base64URL
trans-unit.target: ciphertext-value: cipher text octets, encoded using Base64URL

trans-unit.source: digest-value: The output of a hash algorithm, encoded using Base64URL
trans-unit.target: digest-value: The output of a hash algorithm, encoded using Base64URL

trans-unit.source: key-type: One of the supported key types, for example RSA.
trans-unit.target: key-type: One of the supported key types, for example RSA.

trans-unit.source: plaintext-value: plaintext octets, encoded using Base64URL
trans-unit.target: plaintext-value: plaintext octets, encoded using Base64URL

trans-unit.source: signature-value: The output of a signature algorithm, encoded using Base64URL
trans-unit.target: signature-value: The output of a signature algorithm, encoded using Base64URL

trans-unit.source: base64URL: A Base64URL [RFC4648] encoded binary value
trans-unit.target: base64URL: A Base64URL [RFC4648] encoded binary value

trans-unit.source: boolean: Either true or false
trans-unit.target: boolean: Either true or false

trans-unit.source: Identity: An identity from Azure Active Directory (AAD).
trans-unit.target: Identity: An identity from Azure Active Directory (AAD).

trans-unit.source: IntDate: A JSON decimal value representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z UTC until the specified UTC date/time.
trans-unit.target: IntDate: A JSON decimal value representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z UTC until the specified UTC date/time.

trans-unit.source: See [RFC3339] for details regarding date/times in general and UTC in particular.
trans-unit.target: See [RFC3339] for details regarding date/times in general and UTC in particular.

trans-unit.source: Objects, Identifiers and Versioning
trans-unit.target: Objects, Identifiers and Versioning

trans-unit.source: Objects stored in Azure Key Vault retain versions whenever a new instance of an object is created, and each version has a unique identifier and URL.
trans-unit.target: Objects stored in Azure Key Vault retain versions whenever a new instance of an object is created, and each version has a unique identifier and URL.

trans-unit.source: When an object is first created it is given a unique version identifier and is marked as the current version of the object.
trans-unit.target: When an object is first created it is given a unique version identifier and is marked as the current version of the object.

trans-unit.source: Creation of a new instance with the same object name gives the new object a unique version identifier and causes it to become the current version.
trans-unit.target: Creation of a new instance with the same object name gives the new object a unique version identifier and causes it to become the current version.

trans-unit.source: Objects in Azure Key Vault can be addressed using the current identifier or a version specific identifier.
trans-unit.target: Objects in Azure Key Vault can be addressed using the current identifier or a version specific identifier.

trans-unit.source: For example, given a Key with the name “MasterKey”, performing operations with the current identifier causes the system to use the latest available version.
trans-unit.target: For example, given a Key with the name “MasterKey”, performing operations with the current identifier causes the system to use the latest available version.

trans-unit.source: Performing operations with the version specific identifier causes the system to use that specific version of the object.
trans-unit.target: Performing operations with the version specific identifier causes the system to use that specific version of the object.

trans-unit.source: Objects are uniquely identified within Azure Key Vault using a URL such that no two objects in the system, regardless of geo-location, have the same URL.
trans-unit.target: Objects are uniquely identified within Azure Key Vault using a URL such that no two objects in the system, regardless of geo-location, have the same URL.

trans-unit.source: The complete URL to an object is called the Object Identifier and consists of a prefix portion that identifies the Key Vault, the object type, a user provided Object Name, and an Object Version.
trans-unit.target: The complete URL to an object is called the Object Identifier and consists of a prefix portion that identifies the Key Vault, the object type, a user provided Object Name, and an Object Version.

trans-unit.source: The Object Name is case-insensitive and immutable.
trans-unit.target: The Object Name is case-insensitive and immutable.

trans-unit.source: Identifiers that do not include the Object Version are referred to as Base Identifiers.
trans-unit.target: Identifiers that do not include the Object Version are referred to as Base Identifiers.

trans-unit.source: For more information see, <link xlink:href="4c321939-8a5b-42ca-83c4-2f5f647ca13e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">HTTP Requests and Responses</link>
trans-unit.target: For more information see, <link xlink:href="4c321939-8a5b-42ca-83c4-2f5f647ca13e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">HTTP Requests and Responses</link>

trans-unit.source: A object identifier has the following general format:
trans-unit.target: A object identifier has the following general format:

trans-unit.source: Where:
trans-unit.target: Where:

trans-unit.source: The name for a key vault in the Microsoft Azure Key Vault service.
trans-unit.target: The name for a key vault in the Microsoft Azure Key Vault service.

trans-unit.source: Key Vault names are selected by the user and are globally unique.
trans-unit.target: Key Vault names are selected by the user and are globally unique.

trans-unit.source: Key Vault name must be a string 3-24 characters in length containing only (0-9, a-z, A-Z).
trans-unit.target: Key Vault name must be a string 3-24 characters in length containing only (0-9, a-z, A-Z).

trans-unit.source: The type of the object, either “keys” or “secrets”.
trans-unit.target: The type of the object, either “keys” or “secrets”.

trans-unit.source: An <codeInline>object-name</codeInline> is a user provided name for and must be unique within a Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: An <codeInline>object-name</codeInline> is a user provided name for and must be unique within a Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: The name must be a string 1-127 characters in length containing only 0-9, a-z, A-Z, and -.
trans-unit.target: The name must be a string 1-127 characters in length containing only 0-9, a-z, A-Z, and -.

trans-unit.source: An <codeInline>object-version</codeInline> is a system generated, 32 character string identifier that is optionally used to address a unique version of an object.
trans-unit.target: An <codeInline>object-version</codeInline> is a system generated, 32 character string identifier that is optionally used to address a unique version of an object.

trans-unit.source: Keys and key types
trans-unit.target: Keys and key types

trans-unit.source: Cryptographic keys in Azure Key Vault are represented as JSON Web Key [JWK] objects.
trans-unit.target: Cryptographic keys in Azure Key Vault are represented as JSON Web Key [JWK] objects.

trans-unit.source: The base JWK/JWA specifications are also extended to enable key types unique to the Azure Key Vault implementation, for example the import of keys to Azure Key Vault using the HSM vendor (Thales) specific packaging to enable secure transportation of keys such that they may only be used in the Azure Key Vault HSMs.
trans-unit.target: The base JWK/JWA specifications are also extended to enable key types unique to the Azure Key Vault implementation, for example the import of keys to Azure Key Vault using the HSM vendor (Thales) specific packaging to enable secure transportation of keys such that they may only be used in the Azure Key Vault HSMs.

trans-unit.source: The initial Azure Key Vault release supports RSA keys only; future releases may support other key types such as symmetric and elliptic curve.
trans-unit.target: The initial Azure Key Vault release supports RSA keys only; future releases may support other key types such as symmetric and elliptic curve.

trans-unit.source: RSA: A 2048bit RSA key.
trans-unit.target: RSA: A 2048bit RSA key.

trans-unit.source: This is a "soft" key, which is processed in software by Key Vault but is stored encrypted at rest using a system key that is in an HSM.
trans-unit.target: This is a "soft" key, which is processed in software by Key Vault but is stored encrypted at rest using a system key that is in an HSM.

trans-unit.source: Clients may import an existing RSA key or request that Azure Key Vault generate one.
trans-unit.target: Clients may import an existing RSA key or request that Azure Key Vault generate one.

trans-unit.source: RSA-HSM: An RSA key that is processed in an HSM.
trans-unit.target: RSA-HSM: An RSA key that is processed in an HSM.

trans-unit.source: RSA-HSM keys are protected in one of the Azure Key Vault HSM Security Worlds (there is a Security World per geography to maintain isolation).
trans-unit.target: RSA-HSM keys are protected in one of the Azure Key Vault HSM Security Worlds (there is a Security World per geography to maintain isolation).

trans-unit.source: Clients may import a RSA key, either in soft form or by exporting from a compatible HSM device, or request that Azure Key Vault generate one.
trans-unit.target: Clients may import a RSA key, either in soft form or by exporting from a compatible HSM device, or request that Azure Key Vault generate one.

trans-unit.source: This key type adds the T attribute to the JWK obtain to carry the HSM key material.
trans-unit.target: This key type adds the T attribute to the JWK obtain to carry the HSM key material.

trans-unit.source: For more information on geographical boundaries see, <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Azure Trust Center</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/trust-center/privacy/</linkUri></externalLink>
trans-unit.target: For more information on geographical boundaries see, <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Azure Trust Center</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/trust-center/privacy/</linkUri></externalLink>

trans-unit.source: RSA algorithms
trans-unit.target: RSA algorithms

trans-unit.source: The following algorithm identifiers are supported with RSA keys in Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: The following algorithm identifiers are supported with RSA keys in Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: WRAPKEY/UNWRAPKEY, ENCRYPT/DECRYPT:
trans-unit.target: WRAPKEY/UNWRAPKEY, ENCRYPT/DECRYPT:

trans-unit.source: RSA1_5: RSAES-PKCS1-V1_5 [RFC3447] key encryption
trans-unit.target: RSA1_5: RSAES-PKCS1-V1_5 [RFC3447] key encryption

trans-unit.source: RSA-OAEP: RSAES using Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) [RFC3447], with the default parameters specified by RFC 3447 in Section A.2.1.
trans-unit.target: RSA-OAEP: RSAES using Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) [RFC3447], with the default parameters specified by RFC 3447 in Section A.2.1.

trans-unit.source: Those default parameters are using a hash function of SHA-1 and a mask generation function of MGF1 with SHA-1.
trans-unit.target: Those default parameters are using a hash function of SHA-1 and a mask generation function of MGF1 with SHA-1.

trans-unit.source: SIGN/VERIFY:
trans-unit.target: SIGN/VERIFY:

trans-unit.source: RS256: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.
trans-unit.target: RS256: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

trans-unit.source: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-256 and must be 32 bytes in length.
trans-unit.target: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-256 and must be 32 bytes in length.

trans-unit.source: RS384: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-384.
trans-unit.target: RS384: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-384.

trans-unit.source: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-384 and must be 48 bytes in length.
trans-unit.target: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-384 and must be 48 bytes in length.

trans-unit.source: RS512: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512.
trans-unit.target: RS512: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512.

trans-unit.source: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-512 and must be 64 bytes in length.
trans-unit.target: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-512 and must be 64 bytes in length.

trans-unit.source: RSNULL: See [RFC2437], a specialized use-case to enable certain TLS scenarios.
trans-unit.target: RSNULL: See [RFC2437], a specialized use-case to enable certain TLS scenarios.

trans-unit.source: RSA-HSM algorithms
trans-unit.target: RSA-HSM algorithms

trans-unit.source: The following algorithm identifiers are supported with RSA-HSM keys in Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: The following algorithm identifiers are supported with RSA-HSM keys in Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: WRAP/UNWRAP, ENCRYPT/DECRYPT:
trans-unit.target: WRAP/UNWRAP, ENCRYPT/DECRYPT:

trans-unit.source: RSA1_5: RSAES-PKCS1-V1_5 [RFC3447] key encryption.
trans-unit.target: RSA1_5: RSAES-PKCS1-V1_5 [RFC3447] key encryption.

trans-unit.source: RSA-OAEP: RSAES using Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) [RFC3447], with the default parameters specified by RFC 3447 in Section A.2.1.
trans-unit.target: RSA-OAEP: RSAES using Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) [RFC3447], with the default parameters specified by RFC 3447 in Section A.2.1.

trans-unit.source: Those default parameters are using a hash function of SHA-1 and a mask generation function of MGF1 with SHA-1.
trans-unit.target: Those default parameters are using a hash function of SHA-1 and a mask generation function of MGF1 with SHA-1.

trans-unit.source: SIGN/VERIFY:
trans-unit.target: SIGN/VERIFY:

trans-unit.source: RS256: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.
trans-unit.target: RS256: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

trans-unit.source: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-256 and must be 32 bytes in length.
trans-unit.target: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-256 and must be 32 bytes in length.

trans-unit.source: RS384: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-384.
trans-unit.target: RS384: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-384.

trans-unit.source: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-384 and must be 48 bytes in length.
trans-unit.target: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-384 and must be 48 bytes in length.

trans-unit.source: RS512: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512.
trans-unit.target: RS512: RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512.

trans-unit.source: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-512 and must be 64 bytes in length.
trans-unit.target: The application supplied digest value must be computed using SHA-512 and must be 64 bytes in length.

trans-unit.source: RSNULL: See [RFC2437], a specialized use-case to enable certain TLS scenarios.
trans-unit.target: RSNULL: See [RFC2437], a specialized use-case to enable certain TLS scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Key operations
trans-unit.target: Key operations

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault supports the following operations on key objects:
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault supports the following operations on key objects:

trans-unit.source: Create: Allows a client to create a key in Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Create: Allows a client to create a key in Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: The value of the key is generated by Azure Key Vault and stored and is not released to the client.
trans-unit.target: The value of the key is generated by Azure Key Vault and stored and is not released to the client.

trans-unit.source: Asymmetric (and in the future, Elliptic Curve and Symmetric) keys may be created in Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Asymmetric (and in the future, Elliptic Curve and Symmetric) keys may be created in Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Import: Allows a client to import an existing key to Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Import: Allows a client to import an existing key to Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Asymmetric (and in the future, Elliptic Curve and Symmetric) keys may be imported to Azure Key Vault using a number of different packaging methods within a JWK construct.
trans-unit.target: Asymmetric (and in the future, Elliptic Curve and Symmetric) keys may be imported to Azure Key Vault using a number of different packaging methods within a JWK construct.

trans-unit.source: Update: Allows a client with sufficient permissions to modify the metadata (key attributes) associated with a key previously stored within Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Update: Allows a client with sufficient permissions to modify the metadata (key attributes) associated with a key previously stored within Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Delete: Allows a client with sufficient permissions to delete a key from Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Delete: Allows a client with sufficient permissions to delete a key from Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: List: Allows a client to list all keys in a given Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: List: Allows a client to list all keys in a given Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: List versions: Allows a client to list all versions of a given key in a given Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: List versions: Allows a client to list all versions of a given key in a given Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Get: Allows a client to retrieve the public parts of a given key in an Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Get: Allows a client to retrieve the public parts of a given key in an Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Backup: Exports a key in a protected form.
trans-unit.target: Backup: Exports a key in a protected form.

trans-unit.source: Restore: Imports a previously backed up key.
trans-unit.target: Restore: Imports a previously backed up key.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="e310b13d-4cbc-4c28-9561-407e0a3eebfc" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Managing Key Objects</link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="e310b13d-4cbc-4c28-9561-407e0a3eebfc" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Managing Key Objects</link>

trans-unit.source: Once a key has been created in Azure Key Vault, the following cryptographic operations may be performed using the key:
trans-unit.target: Once a key has been created in Azure Key Vault, the following cryptographic operations may be performed using the key:

trans-unit.source: Sign and Verify: Strictly, this operation is "sign hash" or “verify hash” as Azure Key Vault does not support hashing of content as part of signature creation.
trans-unit.target: Sign and Verify: Strictly, this operation is "sign hash" or “verify hash” as Azure Key Vault does not support hashing of content as part of signature creation.

trans-unit.source: Applications should hash data to be signed locally and then request Azure Key Vault sign the hash.
trans-unit.target: Applications should hash data to be signed locally and then request Azure Key Vault sign the hash.

trans-unit.source: Verification of signed hashes is supported as a convenience operation for applications that may not have access to [public] key material; it is recommended that, for best application performance, verify operations are performed locally.
trans-unit.target: Verification of signed hashes is supported as a convenience operation for applications that may not have access to [public] key material; it is recommended that, for best application performance, verify operations are performed locally.

trans-unit.source: Key Encryption / Wrapping: A key stored in Azure Key Vault may be used to protect another key, typically a symmetric content encryption key (CEK).
trans-unit.target: Key Encryption / Wrapping: A key stored in Azure Key Vault may be used to protect another key, typically a symmetric content encryption key (CEK).

trans-unit.source: When the key in Azure Key Vault is asymmetric, key encryption is used, for example RSA-OAEP and the WRAPKEY/UNWRAPKEY operations are equivalent to ENCRYPT/DECRYPT.
trans-unit.target: When the key in Azure Key Vault is asymmetric, key encryption is used, for example RSA-OAEP and the WRAPKEY/UNWRAPKEY operations are equivalent to ENCRYPT/DECRYPT.

trans-unit.source: When the key in Azure Key Vault is symmetric, key wrapping is used; for example AES-KW.
trans-unit.target: When the key in Azure Key Vault is symmetric, key wrapping is used; for example AES-KW.

trans-unit.source: The WRAPKEY operation is supported as a convenience for applications that may not have access to [public] key material; it is recommended that, for best application performance, WRAPKEY operations are performed locally.
trans-unit.target: The WRAPKEY operation is supported as a convenience for applications that may not have access to [public] key material; it is recommended that, for best application performance, WRAPKEY operations are performed locally.

trans-unit.source: Encrypt and Decrypt: A key stored in Azure Key Vault may be used to encrypt or decrypt a single block of data, the size of which is determined by the key type and selected encryption algorithm.
trans-unit.target: Encrypt and Decrypt: A key stored in Azure Key Vault may be used to encrypt or decrypt a single block of data, the size of which is determined by the key type and selected encryption algorithm.

trans-unit.source: The Encrypt operation is provided for convenience for applications that may not have access to [public] key material; it is recommended that, for best application performance, encrypt operations be performed locally.
trans-unit.target: The Encrypt operation is provided for convenience for applications that may not have access to [public] key material; it is recommended that, for best application performance, encrypt operations be performed locally.

trans-unit.source: While WRAPKEY/UNWRAPKEY using asymmetric keys may seem superfluous as the operation is equivalent to ENCRYPT/DECRYPT, the use of distinct operations is considered important to provide semantic and authorization separation of these operations and consistency when other key types are supported by the service.
trans-unit.target: While WRAPKEY/UNWRAPKEY using asymmetric keys may seem superfluous as the operation is equivalent to ENCRYPT/DECRYPT, the use of distinct operations is considered important to provide semantic and authorization separation of these operations and consistency when other key types are supported by the service.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault does not support EXPORT operations: once a key is provisioned in the system it cannot be extracted or its key material modified.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault does not support EXPORT operations: once a key is provisioned in the system it cannot be extracted or its key material modified.

trans-unit.source: However, users of Azure Key Vault who may require their key for other use cases, or after it has been deleted in Azure Key Vault, may use the BACKUP and RESTORE operations to export/import the key in a protected form.
trans-unit.target: However, users of Azure Key Vault who may require their key for other use cases, or after it has been deleted in Azure Key Vault, may use the BACKUP and RESTORE operations to export/import the key in a protected form.

trans-unit.source: Keys created by the BACKUP operation are not usable outside Azure Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Keys created by the BACKUP operation are not usable outside Azure Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, the IMPORT operation may be used against multiple Azure Key Vault instances.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, the IMPORT operation may be used against multiple Azure Key Vault instances.

trans-unit.source: Users may restrict any of the cryptographic operations that Azure Key Vault supports on a per-key basis using the key_ops property of the JWK object.
trans-unit.target: Users may restrict any of the cryptographic operations that Azure Key Vault supports on a per-key basis using the key_ops property of the JWK object.

trans-unit.source: For more information on JWK objects, see <externalLink><linkText>JSON Web Key (JWK)</linkText><linkUri>http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-jose-json-web-key</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on JWK objects, see <externalLink><linkText>JSON Web Key (JWK)</linkText><linkUri>http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-jose-json-web-key</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Key attributes
trans-unit.target: Key attributes

trans-unit.source: In addition to the key material, the following attributes may be specified.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the key material, the following attributes may be specified.

trans-unit.source: In a JSON Request, the attributes keyword and braces, ‘{‘ ‘}’, are required even if there are no attributes specified.
trans-unit.target: In a JSON Request, the attributes keyword and braces, ‘{‘ ‘}’, are required even if there are no attributes specified.

trans-unit.source: enabled: boolean, optional, default is true.
trans-unit.target: enabled: boolean, optional, default is true.

trans-unit.source: Specifies whether the key is enabled and useable for cryptographic operations.
trans-unit.target: Specifies whether the key is enabled and useable for cryptographic operations.

trans-unit.source: The enabled attribute is used in conjunction with nbf and exp: when an operation occurs between nbf and exp, it will only be permitted if enabled is set to true.
trans-unit.target: The enabled attribute is used in conjunction with nbf and exp: when an operation occurs between nbf and exp, it will only be permitted if enabled is set to true.

trans-unit.source: Operations outside the nbf and exp window are automatically disallowed.
trans-unit.target: Operations outside the nbf and exp window are automatically disallowed.

trans-unit.source: nbf: IntDate, optional, default is now.
trans-unit.target: nbf: IntDate, optional, default is now.

trans-unit.source: The nbf (not before) attribute identifies the time before which the key MUST NOT be used for cryptographic operations.
trans-unit.target: The nbf (not before) attribute identifies the time before which the key MUST NOT be used for cryptographic operations.

trans-unit.source: The processing of the nbf attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be after or equal to the not-before date/time listed in the nbf attribute.
trans-unit.target: The processing of the nbf attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be after or equal to the not-before date/time listed in the nbf attribute.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.

trans-unit.source: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: For more information on IntDate and other data types see, <link xlink:href="abd1b743-1d58-413f-afc1-d08ebf93828a#BKMK_DataTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data types</link>
trans-unit.target: For more information on IntDate and other data types see, <link xlink:href="abd1b743-1d58-413f-afc1-d08ebf93828a#BKMK_DataTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data types</link>

trans-unit.source: exp: IntDate, optional, default is "forever".
trans-unit.target: exp: IntDate, optional, default is "forever".

trans-unit.source: The exp (expiration time) attribute identifies the expiration time on or after which the key MUST NOT be used for cryptographic operation.
trans-unit.target: The exp (expiration time) attribute identifies the expiration time on or after which the key MUST NOT be used for cryptographic operation.

trans-unit.source: The processing of the exp attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be before the expiration date/time listed in the exp attribute.
trans-unit.target: The processing of the exp attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be before the expiration date/time listed in the exp attribute.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.

trans-unit.source: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: There are additional read only attributes that are included in any response that includes key attributes:
trans-unit.target: There are additional read only attributes that are included in any response that includes key attributes:

trans-unit.source: created: IntDate, optional.
trans-unit.target: created: IntDate, optional.

trans-unit.source: The created attribute indicates when this version of the key was created.
trans-unit.target: The created attribute indicates when this version of the key was created.

trans-unit.source: This value is null for keys created prior to the addition of this attribute.
trans-unit.target: This value is null for keys created prior to the addition of this attribute.

trans-unit.source: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: updated: IntDate, optional.
trans-unit.target: updated: IntDate, optional.

trans-unit.source: The updated attribute indicates when this version of the key was updated.
trans-unit.target: The updated attribute indicates when this version of the key was updated.

trans-unit.source: This value is null for keys that were last updated prior to the addition of this attribute.
trans-unit.target: This value is null for keys that were last updated prior to the addition of this attribute.

trans-unit.source: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: For information on data types see, <link xlink:href="abd1b743-1d58-413f-afc1-d08ebf93828a#BKMK_DataTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data types</link>.
trans-unit.target: For information on data types see, <link xlink:href="abd1b743-1d58-413f-afc1-d08ebf93828a#BKMK_DataTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data types</link>.

trans-unit.source: For further information on possible attributes, see the <externalLink><linkText>JSON Web Key (JWK)</linkText><linkUri>http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-jose-json-web-key</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For further information on possible attributes, see the <externalLink><linkText>JSON Web Key (JWK)</linkText><linkUri>http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-jose-json-web-key</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Key tags
trans-unit.target: Key tags

trans-unit.source: You can specify additional application-specific metadata in the form of tags.
trans-unit.target: You can specify additional application-specific metadata in the form of tags.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault supports up to 15 tags, each of which can have a 256 character name and a 256 character value.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault supports up to 15 tags, each of which can have a 256 character name and a 256 character value.

trans-unit.source: Key access control
trans-unit.target: Key access control

trans-unit.source: Access Control for keys managed in Azure Key Vault is provided at the level of a Key Vault that acts as the container of keys.
trans-unit.target: Access Control for keys managed in Azure Key Vault is provided at the level of a Key Vault that acts as the container of keys.

trans-unit.source: There is an access control policy for keys that is distinct from the access control policy for secrets in the same Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: There is an access control policy for keys that is distinct from the access control policy for secrets in the same Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Users may create one or more vaults to hold keys and are required to maintain scenario appropriate segmentation and managed of keys.
trans-unit.target: Users may create one or more vaults to hold keys and are required to maintain scenario appropriate segmentation and managed of keys.

trans-unit.source: Access controls for Keys is independent of Access control for Secrets.
trans-unit.target: Access controls for Keys is independent of Access control for Secrets.

trans-unit.source: The following permissions can be granted, on a per user / service principal basis, in the keys access control entry on a vault.
trans-unit.target: The following permissions can be granted, on a per user / service principal basis, in the keys access control entry on a vault.

trans-unit.source: These permissionsclosely mirror the operations allowed on a key object:
trans-unit.target: These permissionsclosely mirror the operations allowed on a key object:

trans-unit.source: create: Create new keys
trans-unit.target: create: Create new keys

trans-unit.source: get: Read the public part of a key, plus its attributes
trans-unit.target: get: Read the public part of a key, plus its attributes

trans-unit.source: list: List the keys or versions of a key stored in a key vault
trans-unit.target: list: List the keys or versions of a key stored in a key vault

trans-unit.source: update: Update the attributes for a key
trans-unit.target: update: Update the attributes for a key

trans-unit.source: delete: Delete the key object
trans-unit.target: delete: Delete the key object

trans-unit.source: sign: Use the key to sign digests
trans-unit.target: sign: Use the key to sign digests

trans-unit.source: verify: Use the key to verify digests
trans-unit.target: verify: Use the key to verify digests

trans-unit.source: wrapKey: Use the key to protect a symmetric key
trans-unit.target: wrapKey: Use the key to protect a symmetric key

trans-unit.source: unwrapKey: Use the key to unprotect wrapped symmetric keys
trans-unit.target: unwrapKey: Use the key to unprotect wrapped symmetric keys

trans-unit.source: encrypt: Use the key to protect an arbitrary sequence of bytes
trans-unit.target: encrypt: Use the key to protect an arbitrary sequence of bytes

trans-unit.source: decrypt: Use the key to unprotect a sequence of bytes
trans-unit.target: decrypt: Use the key to unprotect a sequence of bytes

trans-unit.source: import: Import a key to a key vault
trans-unit.target: import: Import a key to a key vault

trans-unit.source: backup: Backup a key in a key vault
trans-unit.target: backup: Backup a key in a key vault

trans-unit.source: restore: Restore a backed up key to a key vault
trans-unit.target: restore: Restore a backed up key to a key vault

trans-unit.source: all: All permissions
trans-unit.target: all: All permissions

trans-unit.source: Working with Secrets
trans-unit.target: Working with Secrets

trans-unit.source: Secrets in Azure Key Vault are octet sequences with a maximum size of 25k bytes each.
trans-unit.target: Secrets in Azure Key Vault are octet sequences with a maximum size of 25k bytes each.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Key Vault service does not provide any semantics for secrets; it merely accepts the data and stores it securely, returning a secret identifier, “id”, that may be used to retrieve the secret at a later time.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Key Vault service does not provide any semantics for secrets; it merely accepts the data and stores it securely, returning a secret identifier, “id”, that may be used to retrieve the secret at a later time.

trans-unit.source: For highly sensitive data, clients should consider additional layers of protection for data that is stored in Azure Key Vault; for example by pre-encrypting data using a separate protection key.
trans-unit.target: For highly sensitive data, clients should consider additional layers of protection for data that is stored in Azure Key Vault; for example by pre-encrypting data using a separate protection key.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault also supports a contentType field for secrets.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault also supports a contentType field for secrets.

trans-unit.source: Clients may specify the content type, “contentType”, of a secret to assist in interpreting the secret data when it is retrieved.
trans-unit.target: Clients may specify the content type, “contentType”, of a secret to assist in interpreting the secret data when it is retrieved.

trans-unit.source: The maximum length of this field is 255 characters.
trans-unit.target: The maximum length of this field is 255 characters.

trans-unit.source: There are no pre-defined values.
trans-unit.target: There are no pre-defined values.

trans-unit.source: The suggested usage is as a hint for interpreting the secret data.
trans-unit.target: The suggested usage is as a hint for interpreting the secret data.

trans-unit.source: For instance, an implementation may store both passwords and certificates as secrets then use this field to indicate which.
trans-unit.target: For instance, an implementation may store both passwords and certificates as secrets then use this field to indicate which.

trans-unit.source: Secret attributes
trans-unit.target: Secret attributes

trans-unit.source: In addition to the secret data, the following attributes may be specified:
trans-unit.target: In addition to the secret data, the following attributes may be specified:

trans-unit.source: exp: IntDate, optional, default is "forever".
trans-unit.target: exp: IntDate, optional, default is "forever".

trans-unit.source: The exp (expiration time) attribute identifies the expiration time on or after which the secret data MUST NOT be retrieved.
trans-unit.target: The exp (expiration time) attribute identifies the expiration time on or after which the secret data MUST NOT be retrieved.

trans-unit.source: The processing of the exp attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be before the expiration date/time listed in the exp attribute.
trans-unit.target: The processing of the exp attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be before the expiration date/time listed in the exp attribute.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.

trans-unit.source: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: nbf: IntDate, optional, default is "now".
trans-unit.target: nbf: IntDate, optional, default is "now".

trans-unit.source: The nbf (not before) attribute identifies the time before which the secret data MUST NOT be retrieved.
trans-unit.target: The nbf (not before) attribute identifies the time before which the secret data MUST NOT be retrieved.

trans-unit.source: The processing of the nbf attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be after or equal to the not-before date/time listed in the nbf attribute.
trans-unit.target: The processing of the nbf attribute requires that the current date/time MUST be after or equal to the not-before date/time listed in the nbf attribute.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault MAY provide for some small leeway, usually no more than a few minutes, to account for clock skew.

trans-unit.source: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value MUST be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: enabled: boolean, optional, default is "true".
trans-unit.target: enabled: boolean, optional, default is "true".

trans-unit.source: This attribute specifies whether or not the secret data can be retrieved.
trans-unit.target: This attribute specifies whether or not the secret data can be retrieved.

trans-unit.source: The enabled attribute is used in conjunction with nbf and exp when an operation occurs between nbf and exp, it will only be permitted if enabled is set to true.
trans-unit.target: The enabled attribute is used in conjunction with nbf and exp when an operation occurs between nbf and exp, it will only be permitted if enabled is set to true.

trans-unit.source: Operations outside the nbf and exp window are automatically disallowed.
trans-unit.target: Operations outside the nbf and exp window are automatically disallowed.

trans-unit.source: There are additional read only attributes that are included in any response that includes secret attributes:
trans-unit.target: There are additional read only attributes that are included in any response that includes secret attributes:

trans-unit.source: created: IntDate, optional.
trans-unit.target: created: IntDate, optional.

trans-unit.source: The created attribute indicates when this version of the secret was created.
trans-unit.target: The created attribute indicates when this version of the secret was created.

trans-unit.source: This value is null for secrets created prior to the addition of this attribute.
trans-unit.target: This value is null for secrets created prior to the addition of this attribute.

trans-unit.source: Its value must be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value must be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: updated: IntDate, optional.
trans-unit.target: updated: IntDate, optional.

trans-unit.source: The updated attribute indicates when this version of the secret was updated.
trans-unit.target: The updated attribute indicates when this version of the secret was updated.

trans-unit.source: This value is null for secrets that were last updated prior to the addition of this attribute.
trans-unit.target: This value is null for secrets that were last updated prior to the addition of this attribute.

trans-unit.source: Its value must be a number containing an IntDate value.
trans-unit.target: Its value must be a number containing an IntDate value.

trans-unit.source: For information on data types see, <link xlink:href="abd1b743-1d58-413f-afc1-d08ebf93828a#BKMK_DataTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data types</link>.
trans-unit.target: For information on data types see, <link xlink:href="abd1b743-1d58-413f-afc1-d08ebf93828a#BKMK_DataTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data types</link>.

trans-unit.source: Secret tags
trans-unit.target: Secret tags

trans-unit.source: You can specify additional application-specific metadata in the form of tags.
trans-unit.target: You can specify additional application-specific metadata in the form of tags.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault supports up to 15 tags, each of which can have a 256 character name and a 256 character value.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault supports up to 15 tags, each of which can have a 256 character name and a 256 character value.

trans-unit.source: Secret Access Control
trans-unit.target: Secret Access Control

trans-unit.source: Access Control for secrets managed in Azure Key Vault is provided at the level of a Key Vault that acts as the container of those secrets.
trans-unit.target: Access Control for secrets managed in Azure Key Vault is provided at the level of a Key Vault that acts as the container of those secrets.

trans-unit.source: There is an access control policy for secrets that is distinct from the access control policy for keys in the same Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: There is an access control policy for secrets that is distinct from the access control policy for keys in the same Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Users may create one or more vaults to hold secrets and are required to maintain scenario appropriate segmentation and management of secrets.
trans-unit.target: Users may create one or more vaults to hold secrets and are required to maintain scenario appropriate segmentation and management of secrets.

trans-unit.source: Access controls for secrets is independent of access control for Keys.
trans-unit.target: Access controls for secrets is independent of access control for Keys.

trans-unit.source: The following permissions can be used, on a per-principal basis, in the secrets access control entry on a vault, and closely mirror the operations allowed on a secret object:
trans-unit.target: The following permissions can be used, on a per-principal basis, in the secrets access control entry on a vault, and closely mirror the operations allowed on a secret object:

trans-unit.source: set: Create new secrets
trans-unit.target: set: Create new secrets

trans-unit.source: get: Read a secret
trans-unit.target: get: Read a secret

trans-unit.source: list: List the secrets or versions of a secret stored in a Key Vault
trans-unit.target: list: List the secrets or versions of a secret stored in a Key Vault

trans-unit.source: delete: Delete the secret
trans-unit.target: delete: Delete the secret

trans-unit.source: all: All permissions
trans-unit.target: all: All permissions

trans-unit.source: For more information on working with secrets, see <link xlink:href="9aad221a-8778-4ce0-8aff-cd8d488d7bc3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Secret Operations</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on working with secrets, see <link xlink:href="9aad221a-8778-4ce0-8aff-cd8d488d7bc3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Secret Operations</link>.
